description: From a metathetic variation of gird (“to strike, smite, upbraid, scold, jibe”), from Middle English girden, gerden (“to strike, thrust, smite”, literally “smite with a rod”), from gerd, yerd (“a rod, yard”). More at yard.

verbs.description: gride (third-person singular simple present grides, present participle griding, simple past and past participle grided)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To pierce (something) with a weapon; to wound, to stab.
(obsolete, intransitive, of a weapon or sharp object) To travel through something.
To produce a grinding or scraping sound.
examples: Fiercely fliesThe blast of North and East, and iceMakes daggers at the sharpen’d eaves,And bristles all the brakes and thornsTo yon hard crescent, as she hangsAbove the wood which grides and clangsIts leafless ribs and iron hornsTogether, in the drifts that passTo darken on the rolling brineThat breaks the coast.
